Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effect of Cohesion on Size and Statistics of Avalanches in Granular Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336116
PI: Lehman

1336634
PI: Dahmen

This collaborative project aims at understanding the effect of cohesion on the avalanche statistics in granular materials, and at predicting or minimizing catastrophic avalanches. Experimental results obtained with simple granular bead piles with tunable cohesion will be compared with the predictions of simulations and theoretical models.

The project will systematically study the effects of cohesion on the statistics of slip avalanches on bead piles. Past work has focused on the dynamics of non-cohesive granular materials; new preliminary results show that cohesion can lead to catastrophic effects that cannot be treated as a small perturbation to the non-cohesive studies. The College of Wooster has developed a unique experimental apparatus utilizing magnetic fields to systematically vary the cohesion between steel beads, and the University of Illinois has developed an analytical mean-field model with one shear-stress weakening parameter to model the effects of cohesion on granular materials. The collaborative effort between the two institutions will explore the universal (i.e. detail-independent) effects of cohesion on avalanches and will identify the experimental tuning parameters that determine the size and probability of the catastrophically large avalanches. The experimental system consists of beads that are slowly dropped onto a conical pile that occasionally avalanches. The analysis focuses on statistical properties of the avalanches, such as the probability of particular avalanche sizes and durations, the time between avalanches, and size and recurrence time of the largest events. All of these properties are measured as a function of the amount of cohesion, the amount of initially added energy, the size of the pile, and other experimental parameters. The analytical part of the project uses tools from the theory of phase transitions and the renormalization group to derive predictions for the intermittent avalanches.

Cohesion is relevant to a wide variety of avalanching systems, and these results could ultimately be used to minimize the occurrence of hazardous, catastrophic avalanches in these systems. Understanding the effect of cohesion will also allow better control over the flow of powders, sands, building materials, and agricultural grains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project is to understand the changes in behavior of slip avalanches when cohesion is added into the system. This project is a collaboration between Karin Dahmen at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who does theoretical and modeling work, and Susan Lehman at the College of Wooster (Ohio), who does primarily experimental work. This report focuses on Lehman’s work, since Dahmen’s work was funded separately and will have a separate report.

Slip avalanches occur when a system that has been building up stress suddenly gives way to relieve the stress. An example is the sudden release of stress where two tectonic plates are pushing against each other, resulting in an earthquake. We are interested in these avalanches occurring in granular materials, like powders, sands, and grains, and in particular to understand the effect of cohesion on these systems. In many systems, cohesion (often due to moisture) can cause grains to stick together and then suddenly give way in a dangerous, catastrophically large avalanche. 

PI Lehman has developed a model experiment using magnetism to create a controllable amount of cohesion in steel beads and studies avalanches that occur in a conical pile of beads. Previously, we have studied the statistics of avalanches without cohesion, measuring how frequently they occur and how large they are. We had two main goals for this current work.  First, to develop a method of comparing the experimental results from the beadpile system to the model system and theory so that we could create a comprehensive theory for the effect of cohesion on the statistics of slip avalanches. Second, to extend the capabilities of our experimental system so that we could measure more information about the avalanches, specifically information about the dynamics of individual avalanches. This new information about individual avalanches is needed to better understand the effects of cohesion and to more effectively match up our experimental results with K. Dahmen’s analytical model and predictions.

In order to get this information about the individual avalanches, we have added a high speed camera to the system to record avalanches. We then developed two separate methods to automatically analyze the video to characterize the motion of beads on the pile during the avalanche. The development of these analysis techniques was a major component of the work done during the grant.  Two plots showing motion on the pile during avalanches are shown in the figures as examples. These plots show a top view of the pile and are color-coded according to the average speed of beads on the pile during the avalanche. 

Regarding our first goal, we use K. Dahmen’s simple analytical model as a framework for analysis of avalanche data in this system. We study those properties of the avalanche statistics which we expect to be detail independent, and to use these statistics to investigate the underlying physics. Although the model and the bead pile have very different geometries, we find strong similarities between the experimental results and the model; a set of similarities that together suggest that many of the statistical and time series properties of granular materials with cohesion do not depend on the details of the system.

We find excellent agreement between the statistical properties of avalanches in experimental results for a bead pile with cohesion and the predictions of an analytic model and related simulations for the effect of cohesion on slip avalanches in a sheared solid.  The similar avalanche statistics and time series properties observed in these two distinctly different geometries suggests that the avalanche statistics depends less on the system’s geometry than might be expected, It also suggests the existence of an underlying universality class for avalanche statistics in very different geometries. A paper summarizing these comparisons has been submitted and is currently being revised for publication.

An additional major outcome from this grant was training of six undergraduate students during several 10-week summer research programs.  The PI Lehman directly mentored these students as they learned how to do science – how to conduct research in a reproducible way, how to analyze data, and how to present results clearly.  All of the students presented their results at a local seminar and poster session, and five of them also presented their work in posters at the national meeting of the American Physical Society to further develop their ability to communicate science. 

The PI and the undergraduate students also actively participated in outreach activities, specifically in working with the B-WISER science exploration camp for middle school girls at the College of Wooster. The undergraduate students participate by doing interactive demonstrations on light and waves for the campers each summer. The PI coordinated a large group of students for the demonstrations and also taught multi-day workshops for the campers.
